chapters.content:
Chapter 1 covers air filtration systems, focusing on electronic air cleaners (EACs) and UV air purifiers. The customer can clean EAC cells independently, but a gas technician/fitter should ensure the customer fully understands the cleaning procedures.

To clean cells, carefully slide them out of the cabinet (they may have sharp edges). Wash the cells by either soaking them in a utility sink or placing them in an automatic dishwasher. Take precautions to avoid damaging the ionizing wires. Use detergent for cleaning, following manufacturer instructions. After washing, check the cells for dirt or residue and repeat washing if necessary. Before reassembling the EAC, clean the pre-filter by washing with detergent or vacuuming it. Do not wash the pre-filter in the dishwasher. Do not soak the pre-filter at the same time as the cells, as lint from the pre-filter can become caught in the cells. Before reassembling, check the ionizing wires and replace any that are broken. If the EAC has a drying unit, activate it before turning the system back on. Turn the power back on at the main disconnect.

Some EACs will not operate until they are completely dry. Others may operate when wet but could experience arcing if the cells and pre-filters are damp. If the unit has a check LED, it may light when wet. To avoid problems, leave the EAC turned off for 2 to 3 h to allow complete drying.

For the dishwasher method, before using a dishwasher to clean the cells, check the dishwasher's manual as some manufacturers advise against washing electronic cells. If suitable, place the cells on the bottom rack with the airflow arrows pointing up, ensuring good water circulation. Do not place other items in the dishwasher with the cells. Use regular dishwashing detergent. Run the cells through a complete wash cycle but do not allow the dishwasher to run the dry cycle. The dry cycle can bake on any remaining contaminants and reduce an air cleaner's efficiency. Allow the cells to cool completely in the dishwasher. If removed while still warm, wear protective gloves to avoid burns. Be cautious, as hot water may accumulate in the tubes supporting the collector plates. Tip the cells to drain any accumulated water from the tubes. Gently wipe the ionizer wires and the contact board at the end of the cell with a small damp cloth. If dirt or residue remains in the dishwasher, run an empty wash cycle.

For the soaking method, use a container or utility sink large enough to fully immerse one or both cells. Fill the container with very hot water. Dissolve 3/4 cup of regular automatic dishwashing detergent per cell in the hot water. If the detergent does not dissolve easily or forms a scum, use softened water or try another brand. Once the detergent is fully dissolved, lower the cell(s) into the container and soak each cell for 15 to 20 min. Move the cells up and down a few times in the solution then remove the cells from the container. Rinse the cells thoroughly with a fine water spray. Soak them again in clean, hot water for 5 to 15 min to remove any remaining detergent. Stand the cells upright and allow them to drain and dry. Do not soak the cells in a bathtub, as their sharp edges may scratch the finish on the tub.

The fine tungsten wires in the charging section of the electronic cell are brittle and prone to breaking or damage. Show the customer how to inspect the cell from the upstream side to ensure no wires are broken or out of position. Broken wires can cause visible arcing or sparking, which indicates the need for replacement. Replacement wires are pre-cut to the correct length and have eyelets on both ends for easy installation. To replace broken wires, remove the broken wire ensuring all parts are fully removed, taking care not to damage the spring connector. Hook the eyelet of the replacement ionization wire onto the spring connector at one end of the cell. Hold the opposite eyelet with needle nose pliers and stretch the wire along the length of the cell. Depress the opposite spring connector and hook the eyelet onto it securely. Always ensure the power supply is turned off before performing maintenance on an EAC.

While customers can clean cells and replace ionizing wires, all other maintenance and service must be performed by a trained gas technician/fitter. Before the beginning of the heating and cooling seasons, inspect the solid-state components and ionizing wires of the EAC. Always consult manufacturer instructions. Checking components requires a voltmeter or multimeter. Ensure the power from the main disconnect to the EAC is in the "on" position. To check the operation of the sail switch (or electrical blower interlock), energize the furnace blower. If the EAC does not operate, the sail switch may be faulty. Check to confirm that the voltage indicator light is on. If the light is not on but the unit operates, it is the light that is faulty. Press the test button on the EAC access door. Pushing the button shorts the hot side of the collector section to ground, producing one or more loud snapping sounds which indicates that the EAC is working properly. The test button also discharges the cells. Remove the access door. With the voltmeter or multimeter set to ac, check the voltage to the power pack. It should read 120 V ac. If the power pack is not working, you can replace the solid-state power supply within the power supply box. To charge particles, EACs operate at high voltage. Follow manufacturer instructions carefully when servicing them to avoid hazards.

For troubleshooting, investigate visible arcing or sparks and any strong ozone odour. If there is visible arcing or sparking, use an ohmmeter to check the cell for short circuits. Ensure the power to the EAC is turned off and cells are fully discharged. Measure the resistance between the frame of the cell and ionizer as well as between the frame of the cell and collector contacts. In both cases, the resistance should read as infinite. If a cell is sparking continuously in one place, reposition the plates per manufacturer's instructions. If the customer complains of an ozone odour, verify the air cleaner turns off when the furnace blower is inactive and ensure sufficient airflow is passing through the unit.

UV light rays lie in the spectrum of light that is invisible to most humans. UV lights are designed to create a specific wavelength range within the electromagnetic spectrum of UV radiation. The common UV lamps used in air purification systems are: UVC (ultraviolet C) range is germicidal and commonly used for air sterilization, UVC lamps effectively destroy microorganisms that pass by the bulb including germs, viruses, bacteria, and fungi such as mould; VUV (vacuum UV) lights can help reduce gaseous contaminants and odours such as volatile organic compounds; UVA (ultraviolet A) combined with a catalyst reduces odours and chemicals.

The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared light, visible light, ultraviolet light, X-rays, gamma rays, and cosmic rays. UV wavelengths range from 100 nm (vacuum UV ozone producing) to 400 nm (long wave UVA), with UVC (short wave germicidal) at 200-280 nm and UVB (middle wave) at 280-315 nm.

UVC light is as harmful to the eyes as looking directly at the sun. Skin exposure can lead to burns and exposure to the blue light given off by UVC light bulbs can result in significant eye damage. UV light degrades plastic components and wire insulation, so ensure these materials are not exposed to UV light.

The basic UVC lamp device (germicidal UV lamp) is designed to fit into various locations within the supply or return air duct but is often installed near the cooling coil to reduce mould and bacteria in the coil fins, drain pans, and surrounding surfaces. Continuous operation of both the air handler motor and the UVC germicidal lamp ensures maximum exposure of airborne contaminants to UVC light. Advantages include: can destroy microorganisms such as germs, viruses, bacteria, and fungi including mould; helps prevent illnesses and diseases; does not produce ozone. Disadvantages include: no effect on particulates including most allergens; no effect on chemical fumes, gases, or cigarette smoke; degrades plastic, nylon, and rubber parts.

UV lamps are integrated into systems that purify and filter air and are often combined with HEPA or charcoal filters. These systems can function as standalone units, partial bypass arrangements, or insert units. However, they do not replace the inline air filter which remains essential in protecting the fan. Different UV lights may be used depending on the type of air treatment being performed. Do not assume that all UV systems have germicidal capabilities. Some UV lights are designed to produce both UVC and VUV light. A VUV light unit produces a small amount of ozone which may be noticeable.

assignment_questions.question: Which side of an electrostatic filter would load up first?
assignment_questions.explanation: The upstream side of an electrostatic filter would load up first as it is the first surface to encounter airborne particles.

assignment_questions.question: A/An _______ type of air filter is usually the least expensive.
assignment_questions.explanation: Media type air filters are usually the least expensive compared to electronic, electrostatic, or UV purifier systems.

assignment_questions.question: When installing an activated carbon filter with an EAC, where should it be located?
assignment_questions.explanation: An activated carbon filter should be located downstream of the EAC to filter odors and chemical fumes after particles have been removed by the EAC.

assignment_questions.question: To reduce smoke odours, a/an _______ type of air filter is recommended.
assignment_questions.explanation: An activated carbon filter is recommended to reduce smoke odours as it is designed to absorb gases, odors, and chemical fumes.

assignment_questions.question: If there are arrows on a filter frame, which way must they face?
assignment_questions.explanation: Arrows on a filter frame must face with the flow direction to ensure proper filtration and prevent damage to the filter media.

assignment_questions.question: Because electrostatic filters are a form of slab filter, they are installed in the same position (and manner) as slab filters.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. Electrostatic filters are a form of slab filter and are installed in the same position and manner as standard slab filters.

assignment_questions.question: Before opening the blower door on a forced-air furnace, you should always disconnect the power supply.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. Always disconnect the power supply before opening the blower door on a forced-air furnace for safety reasons.

assignment_questions.question: During the heating season, furnace filters should be inspected _______.
assignment_questions.explanation: During the heating season, furnace filters should be inspected monthly to ensure proper airflow and system efficiency.

assignment_questions.question: Filters should be replaced _______.
assignment_questions.explanation: Filters should be replaced at least twice a year, typically at the beginning of the heating and cooling seasons, or more frequently if needed.

assignment_questions.question: On an existing system without any modifications, what is the most common cause of inadequate heating or cooling performance?
assignment_questions.explanation: Dirty filters are the most common cause of inadequate heating or cooling performance on an existing system without modifications, as they restrict airflow.

assignment_questions.question: What damage can a dirty filter do in a system that includes add-on air conditioning?
assignment_questions.explanation: A dirty filter can cause refrigerant floodback, compressor damage, and decreased cooling performance in a system with add-on air conditioning.

assignment_questions.question: The pre-filter of an EAC serves the same purpose as the filter in the furnace blower compartment; therefore, that filter should be removed when an EAC is installed.
assignment_questions.explanation: False. The pre-filter of an EAC does not replace the furnace blower compartment filter. Both filters serve different purposes and should remain in place.

assignment_questions.question: What can happen if ionizer wires are broken?
options: The sail switch may remain open
Arcing and sparking may become visible
The voltage indicator light may turn on
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Arcing and sparking may become visible
assignment_questions.explanation: If ionizer wires are broken, arcing and sparking may become visible, indicating the need for wire replacement.

assignment_questions.question: After washing the cells of an EAC, leave the EAC turned off for 2 to 3 h (until the cells and pre-filter are completely dry) to avoid problems.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. After washing EAC cells, leave the unit turned off for 2 to 3 h until completely dry to avoid arcing and operational problems.

assignment_questions.question: When the cells are washed in a dishwasher, why should the drying cycle not be run?
options: Because the cell coating will be damaged
Because heat will damage the cells' magnetic properties
Because any remaining contaminants will be baked onto cells
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Because any remaining contaminants will be baked onto cells
assignment_questions.explanation: The drying cycle should not be run because any remaining contaminants will be baked onto the cells, reducing the air cleaner's efficiency.

assignment_questions.question: To ensure customers have the best air quality, it is recommended to always install a filter with the highest MERV rating.
assignment_questions.explanation: False. Installing the highest MERV rating filter is not always recommended as it can restrict airflow. The filter should be matched to the system's capabilities and the customer's needs.

assignment_questions.question: A HEPA filter is best installed as a standalone system or a partial bypass system.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. A HEPA filter is best installed as a standalone system or a partial bypass system due to its high resistance to airflow.

assignment_questions.question: _______ type lights are most commonly used for germicidal air treatment.
assignment_questions.explanation: UVC (ultraviolet C) type lights are most commonly used for germicidal air treatment as they are effective at destroying microorganisms.

assignment_questions.question: When installing a UV air treatment bypass system or a HEPA bypass system, you must remove the furnace inline blower compartment filter.
assignment_questions.explanation: False. The furnace inline blower compartment filter must not be removed when installing UV or HEPA bypass systems, as it remains essential for protecting the fan.

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers humidifiers. Hard water can create various problems in humidifiers. Nozzles, tubes, and evaporative elements may accumulate precipitated solids and become clogged. Mineral solids that enter the air stream can, after distribution, leave a layer of white dust on furniture and floors throughout the home.

Solutions to avoid hard water problems include: soften the humidifier's water (usually involves adding sodium to the water, however since sodium itself precipitates out in humidifier reservoirs over time, ensure that the reservoir is periodically flushed out); add chemicals to the humidifier pan that prevent scaling (mineral precipitation), however consult the manufacturer's literature before adding any chemicals; connect to the water supply by installing a full-size tee fitting and approved valve on the water line.

For a copper water tubing system, a saddle valve may come with the installation package from the humidifier manufacturer. Though considered "easy to install", this type of connection is not recommended as the saddle valve is prone to failure and can cause enormous property damage. In Ontario, the Ontario Building Code states that a saddle valve "shall not be installed".

Atomizing humidifiers installed in a duct or plenum must operate only when the furnace blower is operating. These humidifiers introduce droplets of water into the ducts, which can lead to problems. Without air movement, water droplets can settle on duct surfaces and cause moisture accumulation. Standing moisture creates a breeding ground for mildew, which compromises indoor air quality. Moisture can cause corrosion. An electrical interlock is required to ensure that an atomizing humidifier works only when the blower is operating. This is accomplished by installing a sail switch in the return air duct. When the blower is energized, air movement causes a fin on the sail switch to move, closing a set of electrical contacts to the atomizing humidifier and energizing it.

In contrast, evaporative (wetted element) humidifiers can operate independently of the furnace, so no interlock is required. Power bypass humidifiers include a transformer. A humidifier must not be connected to the transformer (if there is one) on the furnace because this could overload the furnace transformer. A humidifier transformer should not be wired into the thermostat circuit. If it was, the thermostat would receive a different current draw if the humidistat calls for moisture. If a humidifier transformer is installed on a furnace with a direct drive motor, the wiring and control system must prevent the humidifier transformer from overvoltage created by the motor's idle windings. Follow all manufacturer's wiring diagrams.

Make modifications to the sheet metal when a humidifier is installed in or under a duct, in a plenum, or in a bypass duct. Follow manufacturer's instructions regarding the size of the openings required and proper sealing of openings for the specific humidifier.

Ideally all the water flowing into a humidifying unit would evaporate; in reality however, there is usually leftover water. The common solution for leftover water is to provide a drain tube, but this means that the humidifier must have access to a drainpipe. In some designs, the water is retained and recycled until it all evaporates. The pros of this approach include the drainless design and conservation of water; the cons include the increased need for cleaning and maintenance and the potential for mould growth if the water is allowed to sit.

Prior to the start of the heating season, the operation of the humidifier should be checked at the same time as the forced-air furnace is inspected. It is particularly important to make sure that the humidifier is clean before the heating season starts. If water remains in a humidifier for an extended period (e.g., over the summer), it creates a breeding environment for fungi, bacteria, algae, and viruses. If the reservoir is not cleaned before the furnace blower is turned on, these microorganisms may be distributed throughout the house, resulting in reduced indoor air quality and increased indoor air pollution.

Common operational requirements include correct water level (if too high, water can overflow into ducts causing corrosion and mildew, must be set to manufacturer's specifications), float valve assembly operating (must be working and adjusted properly to maintain correct water level), working humidistat (check operation with independent measurement such as sling psychrometer), and clean overflow/drain line and reservoir pan (hose may need removal for cleaning, ensure drain not blocked, clean reservoir pan at beginning and end of heating season or more frequently if slimy, ensure customer understands cleaning per manufacturer instructions).

Service guidelines vary by type. Wetted-element humidifiers: if mounted on drum or paddle, must turn for correct operation, clean or replace media at start of each season, keep pad clean for proper water absorption and evaporation, wash with detergent if cleanable, lightly scrape mineral deposits with putty knife if needed, replace pad if no longer conforms to drum after cleaning. Atomizing humidifiers: confirm nozzle sprays freely and drum rotates. Steam humidifiers: verify steam generation, check for nozzle blockages, check steam hose for low spots and ensure slopes continuously upward from humidifier to dispersion tube, if dispersion tube below humidifier inspect drip tee drain and trap, examine canister for loose electrical connections. Wetted-element spray humidifiers: inspect spray nozzles for dirt or mineral deposits. Drum-type humidifiers: clutch assembly must be inspected and cleaned regularly, clean mineral deposits from clutch assembly, clean drain pan, clean orifice between water source and float valve, turn on blower, set humidistat to call, confirm motor rotates properly, adjust water level screw.

Customer seasonal maintenance instructions: Fall: clean media pad before heating season begins (if applicable), clean reservoir with vinegar and water (if applicable), open bypass duct damper (if bypass type), check and adjust float level as needed, set humidistat to desired relative humidity approximately 40%. Winter: check windows for condensation indicating excess humidity and adjust as necessary, periodically check water level. Summer: drain humidifier reservoir, close bypass duct damper (if applicable).

When a customer reports lack of humidity, check the relative humidity in the conditioned space using a sling psychrometer and troubleshoot the humidifier, especially the humidistat, water supply, and electrical system. In extreme weather conditions, few humidifiers can provide the desired humidity level.

A sling psychrometer is used to measure air temperature using two thermometers (wet bulb and dry bulb) mounted on a base with a handle that allows it to rotate rapidly in the air. As the psychrometer moves, air flows over the thermometers. Moisture evaporates from the wet bulb. Once temperatures stabilize on the two thermometers, readings are taken from both and compared with tables to find the relative humidity. Modern electronic devices can measure relative humidity without requiring a sling action, making them more convenient. These devices operate based on temperature of condensation, changes in electrical resistance, and changes in electrical capacitance. A digital psychrometer provides quick and accurate relative humidity measurements.

Troubleshooting the humidifier includes checking the humidistat (set to higher level to verify activation, if functioning but not calling for correct RH may be incorrectly calibrated, recalibrate or replace, if outdoor temperature reading not accurate ensure sensor securely connected, check location and mounting, measure resistance and compare to manufacturer table), water supply (ensure supply line not plugged and float valve adjusted properly, if float damaged replace immediately, if overflows and level/float correct the seat on entire float assembly may need replacement, for wetted element ensure medium not clogged/dirty/saturated with minerals, clean if possible or replace, replace damaged elements to prevent liquid water entering ducts, for atomizing verify drum turning and spray nozzle not blocked), and electrical connections (check circuit breakers, humidistat, low-voltage controls, if motor check if burned out or malfunctioning, mineral deposits may cause thermal fault overload protector to open shutting unit off, clean or replace component).

Other potential problems that should be addressed include excessive dust (white due to mineral buildup, clean or replace media), moisture in ducts (atomizing humidifier operating when blower not on, ensure synchronized to operate only when blower on and furnace operating, verify will not operate in "fan only" mode as heat required to evaporate droplets), and water overflow (inspect float valve for proper adjustment, clean/replace/adjust valve, check drainage/overflow line for blockages).

assignment_questions.question: What is the (approximate) ideal level of relative humidity for optimum comfort in a residence?
assignment_questions.explanation: The ideal level of relative humidity for optimum comfort in a residence is approximately 40%.

assignment_questions.question: Which type of humidifier has a water reservoir that the wetted element is drawn through?
assignment_questions.explanation: A drum humidifier has a water reservoir that the wetted element (mounted on a drum) is drawn through as the drum rotates.

assignment_questions.question: Atomizing humidifiers introduce droplets of water into the air.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. Atomizing humidifiers introduce droplets of water into the air through a spray nozzle.

assignment_questions.question: Why should atomizing humidifiers operate only when the furnace blower is operating?
options: Because water can collect in the ducts
Because humidity levels in the building can get too high
Because the outdoor air temperature cannot be sensed
Because the furnace heat exchanger has cooled to low
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Because water can collect in the ducts
assignment_questions.explanation: Atomizing humidifiers should operate only when the furnace blower is operating because without air movement, water droplets can settle on duct surfaces causing moisture accumulation, mildew, and corrosion.

assignment_questions.question: How must the steam supply hose or pipe be installed on a self-contained steam humidifier?
options: Looped to create a running trap
Pitched down from dispersion tube to humidifier
Pitched down from humidifier to dispersion tube
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Pitched down from humidifier to dispersion tube
assignment_questions.explanation: The steam supply hose or pipe must be pitched down from humidifier to dispersion tube (sloping continuously upward from humidifier to dispersion tube) to ensure proper steam flow and prevent condensate accumulation.

assignment_questions.question: The humidistat is normally mounted on the supply air duct.
assignment_questions.explanation: False. The humidistat is normally mounted on the return air duct or in the living space to sense the actual humidity level in the home.

assignment_questions.question: Why do digital humidistats on automatic mode adjust the building humidity based on outside air temperature?
options: Because colder days require lower indoor relative humidity for optimal comfort
Because warmer days require lower indoor relative humidity for optimal comfort
Because colder days require lower indoor relative humidity to avoid interior condensation
Because warmer days require lower indoor relative humidity to avoid interior condensation
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Because colder days require lower indoor relative humidity to avoid interior condensation
assignment_questions.explanation: Digital humidistats on automatic mode adjust building humidity based on outside air temperature because colder days require lower indoor relative humidity to avoid interior condensation on windows and other cold surfaces.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ device controls the operation of a humidifier.
assignment_questions.explanation: A humidistat device controls the operation of a humidifier by sensing humidity levels and turning the humidifier on or off to maintain desired relative humidity.

assignment_questions.question: If a humidifier is used in a system with an EAC, where should the humidifier be mounted?
assignment_questions.explanation: If a humidifier is used in a system with an EAC, the humidifier should be mounted downstream of the EAC to prevent moisture from affecting the EAC's operation.

assignment_questions.question: If not cleaned, the water-holding reservoir of a drum humidifier may allow the breeding of bacteria that can be dispersed throughout a house.
assignment_questions.explanation: True. If not cleaned, the water-holding reservoir can breed fungi, bacteria, algae, and viruses that can be distributed throughout the house when the blower operates, resulting in reduced indoor air quality.

chapters.content:
Chapter 3 covers cooling coils. Refrigeration and air conditioning mechanics (not gas technicians/fitters) are responsible for the installation and major servicing of cooling coils used with gas-fired forced-air furnaces. However, a gas technician/fitter must inspect and clean the cooling coils as part of regular furnace servicing.

Normal air temperature rise or drop is the difference between supply and return air temperatures. A cooling coil (sometimes called an "A-coil" because of its shape) can be added to a forced-air furnace, which enables it to function as a central air conditioner. While air conditioning technicians handle the installation and servicing of air conditioning units, gas technicians/fitters are responsible for cleaning the cooling coil as part of regular furnace maintenance. A dirty coil (like a dirty furnace filter) can restrict airflow.

This type of air conditioning system consists of a cooling coil (evaporator) and a condenser. The cooling coil may be mounted in the supply plenum or housed in a cabinet located between the supply plenum and the duct. The condenser is usually located outside the building.

This type of air conditioning system works as follows. Two lines circulate refrigerant between the A-coil and condenser coil. The compressor moves the refrigerant around the loop. As the furnace forces air through the A-coil, the coil absorbs heat from the air, causing the liquid refrigerant to evaporate into vapour. The vapour moves to the condenser coil, where heat is released outdoors, causing the refrigerant vapour to return to its liquid state. The liquid refrigerant then returns to the cooling coil.

The refrigerant vapor compression cycle includes a low pressure side (evaporator, expansion device with liquid/vapor mix, saturated/subcooled liquid) and a high pressure side (compressor, condenser with superheated vapor, saturated/subcooled vapor). Cooling coil units are available for upflow, downflow, and horizontal furnaces. The coil is housed in a cabinet. Possible locations of the cooling coil cabinet vary by furnace type.

To measure either the temperature drop across a cooling coil or the temperature rise across the heat exchanger, punch or drill holes in the supply and return air plenums, aiming to position the holes about 3 ft from the furnace when possible. Insert a thermometer into the airflow through each hole. Most good-quality electronic multimeters have a temperature probe accessory or a pocket digital thermometer that can be used. Operate the equipment with the fan running for about 5 min to establish the normal air temperature rise or drop (which is the difference between supply air temperature and return air temperature). To calculate temperature drop across the coil, subtract the supply-side temperature from the return-side temperature. To calculate temperature rise across the heat exchanger, subtract the return-side temperature from the supply-side temperature.

To diagnose temperature change, note that the temperature drop across the cooling coil is about 11 C (20 F) when it is operating at typical condition of 24 C (75 F) and 50% relative humidity. If the measured temperature drop is too low, inspect the cooling coil unit and clean it if necessary. Check the blower and adjust it as required. Refer to the manufacturer's manual for the correct temperature drop and air volume. Clean the unit and retest the temperature drop before adjusting the blower speed. If needed, adjust the blower speed to obtain the correct pressure drop and air volume. If the blower is not operating correctly, you will need to refer the customer to a refrigeration and air conditioning mechanic to troubleshoot the cooling system.

The surfaces of the cooling coil must be clean to maintain system performance and efficiency. A dirty coil can cause several problems including: during the cooling season, the coil will not deliver its full cooling capacity; the airflow to the building will be reduced; during the heating season, both the temperature rise across the furnace and the stack temperature may increase. The coil must be visually inspected for cleanliness as part of regular furnace maintenance. If the coil is located in a cabinet, an access door is typically included in the case coil cabinet. If mounted in the plenum, it may be necessary to cut an inspection port (if so, be careful not to damage the coil).

The cooling coil requires cleaning when it is dirty. A gas technician/fitter is responsible for cleaning the exterior of the coil and the fins through which air is forced over the coil. Cleaning procedures may differ by unit. Always consult manufacturer instructions for specifics.

A typical cleaning procedure includes: check the fins for accumulated dirt or dust, if the fins are clogged or dirty clean them using a vacuum cleaner, compressed air or nitrogen, or a brush or a fin comb (handle tools carefully to avoid damaging the coil); inspect the tubing and connections for signs of oil leaks (look for oil spots, if you find leaks refer the necessary repair to an air conditioning technician); clean the outer surfaces of lines using a vacuum cleaner or brush to remove dirt, wash the outer surfaces with low-pressure water and mild detergent if necessary; check and clean the condensate drain system; remove any accumulated dust or dirt from the drip tray, probe the drain hole with a screwdriver to ensure it is not clogged, pour a small amount of water into the drip tray and confirm proper drainage, blow out clogged drains with compressed air or nitrogen.

assignment_questions.question: Refrigerant circulates between the "A" coil and the condenser coil. Which of the following occurs in the A-coil?
options: Liquid refrigerant absorbs heat and changes into vapour
Vaporous refrigerant absorbs heat and changes into liquid
Heat is removed, causing the vaporous refrigerant to return to liquid
Heat is removed, causing the liquid refrigerant to change to vapour
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Liquid refrigerant absorbs heat and changes into vapour
assignment_questions.explanation: In the A-coil (evaporator), as the furnace forces air through the coil, the coil absorbs heat from the air, causing the liquid refrigerant to evaporate into vapour.

assignment_questions.question: Refrigerant circulates between the "A" coil and the condenser coil. Which of the following occurs outside of the condenser coil?
options: Liquid refrigerant absorbs heat and changes into vapour
Vaporous refrigerant absorbs heat and changes into liquid
Heat is removed, causing the vaporous refrigerant to return to liquid
Heat is removed, causing the liquid refrigerant to change to vapour
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Heat is removed, causing the vaporous refrigerant to return to liquid
assignment_questions.explanation: At the condenser coil (located outside), heat is released outdoors, causing the refrigerant vapour to return to its liquid state.

assignment_questions.question: How would a dirty cooling coil affect the temperature change of a forced-air furnace during the cooling season?
assignment_questions.explanation: A dirty cooling coil restricts airflow and reduces heat transfer, causing the temperature drop across the coil to decrease during the cooling season. The coil will not deliver its full cooling capacity.

assignment_questions.question: If the static pressure across a coil is beyond the manufacturer's suggested limits, what should you do first?
assignment_questions.explanation: If the static pressure is beyond manufacturer's suggested limits, you should first clean the unit (including the coil and filter) and retest before adjusting the blower speed.

assignment_questions.question: A dirty cooling coil can restrict airflow. What would be the effect of restricted airflow on the temperature change of a forced-air furnace during the heating season?
assignment_questions.explanation: A dirty cooling coil restricts airflow. During the heating season, restricted airflow causes the temperature rise across the furnace to increase (as well as the stack temperature) because less air is moving across the heat exchanger.

CSA Unit 23 - Forced Air Add-On 
Devices
Chapter 1                                         Air 
Filters and Cleaners for Forced-
Air Furnaces
A forced-air furnace cannot operate without air filtration. The gas technician/fitter 
must be familiar with the various types of filters available, be able to install them 
correctly, and instruct customers on their maintenance to ensure safe, efficient 
operation of the gas furnace.
It is important for the gas technician/fitter to understand the advantages and 
disadvantages of media and electrostatic filters and electronic air cleaners, so they 
can help customers choose the air filtration system best suited to their needs.
MK by Mike Kapin

Copywrite 2025

Term

Types of Air Filtration Systems
Media Filters
Sometimes called mechanical filters, they are the simplest form 
of air filtration. They are made from such media as fibreglass 
and positioned in the air stream.
Air is forced through the filter and particles removed. The filter 
media can be reusable or disposable.
Media filters of high, low, and medium efficiency are available.
Electrostatic Air Filters
These are media filters made from a material that generates a 
static charge in response to air flow.
The static charge attracts and holds more particles than media 
filters to the medium.
Electronic Air Cleaners (EAC)
They use an electrostatic charge to remove and collect 
particulate contaminants from the circulated air system.
An EAC uses an external power source to generate the charge 
that attracts particles to charged plates, rather than a media 
filter, to collect them.
UV Air Purifier
Use UV light to reduce biological contaminants, chemical, and 
odours. UV is not a filtration method, but can be incorporated 
into filtration systems.
Understanding MERV Ratings
What is MERV?
The minimum efficiency reporting value (MERV) is a numerical value given to furnace filters to identify the filtering ability.
The MERV rating system is now an international industry standard that helps determine a furnace filter's ability to capture and hold dirt 
and dust in specific size ranges.
Rating Scale
MERV ratings range from 120. The higher the MERV rating, the greater the filtering capability. Measurements are in microns.
Applications
High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA), MERV 1720, or high-efficiency particulate arrestance filters, which remove a very high 
percentage of airborne contaminants, are often specified for various commercial, industrial, and institutional applications.
Residential Use
A MERV rating between eight and 11 is adequate for most homes. To be safe, it is best to check if the furnace manufacturer has a 
maximum MERV rating for the model of furnace being used.
Pressure Drop Considerations
What is Pressure Drop?
The pressure drop that the filter 
causes should undergo assessment 
for suitability with fan units prior to 
use to ensure maintenance of duct 
static pressures.
As filters become more efficient 
(higher MERV ratings), they typically 
create more resistance to airflow, 
which can affect system performance.
Impact on System
Too much pressure drop can cause:

Reduced airflow through the 
system

Decreased heating and cooling 
efficiency

Increased energy consumption

Potential damage to the furnace 
components
Finding Balance
The ideal filter provides adequate 
filtration while maintaining proper 
airflow through the system.
Always consult manufacturer 
specifications for maximum allowable 
pressure drop in the system.
Sources of Indoor Air Particles
Household Dust
Dust on floors or other 
surfaces that is disturbed by 
activity in the house
Combustion Sources
Dust generated by smoking, 
burning candles, cooking, 
doing laundry, etc.
Biological Sources
Hair and skin flakes from 
humans or pets
Outdoor Sources
Particles from the outside air 
that come into the home 
with infiltrating air
Health Impacts of Airborne Particles
Visible Particles
Particles of dust that accumulate on a television screen, shelves, and furniture are visible to the eyes
Respirable Particles
Some particles are so small that they are inhaled and then exhaled without 
being trapped in the lungs
Harmful Particles
The particles most dangerous to humans are those that 
enter the lungs and lodge there
Although an occupant would probably like to keep visible dust out of a home, the main health risk comes from unseen/unsafe 
particles which include tobacco smoke, spores, bacteria, and viruses.
Choosing the Right Air Filtration System
Air Quality Requirements
Consider the degree of air cleanliness required for the 
specific application
Dust Conditions
Evaluate the amount and type of dust in the air to be 
filtered
Airflow Resistance
Consider the operating resistance to air flow (pressure 
drop)
Space Constraints
Assess the space available for filtration equipment
Cost Factors
Evaluate initial costs, ongoing maintenance costs, and 
operating costs
System Lifespan
Consider the predicted life and efficiency of the 
system

Types of Media Filters
Hammock Filters
Located on a frame or 
hammock that 
surrounds the fan in

If a forced-air furnace

Slab Filters
Consist of layers of 
filter material, usually

by a cardboard frame
The fibres are treated 
with oil or a similar 
adhesive
Most slab filters are 
designed for one-time 
use and must be 
discarded when they 
are dirty

Represent the most 
popular type of filter 
choice available today
Come in a variety of

Paper pleating 
increases the filter

Hammock Filter
Description
Hammock filters are located on a frame 
or hammock that surrounds the fan in the 
forced-air furnace.
The filter material is typically disposable 
and requires periodic replacement.
Installation
If a forced-air furnace is intended to be 
used with a hammock filter, the filter 
holder will be factory installed.
The filter material is secured to the frame 
with screws or clips that can be loosened 
for replacement.
Maintenance
Regular inspection and replacement of 
the filter material is necessary.
One side of the media is usually coated 
with oil to enhance particle collection. 
This coated side should be opposite the 
blower.
Slab and Pleated Filters
Filter Rack Installation
Locate the Installation Position
Identify the location of the racks. The side of the furnace cabinet will 
likely have embossed angles indicating the location.
Cut the Return Opening
Cut the return opening using the angles as guides.
Mount the Filter Rack
Mount the filter rack over the opening.
Complete Ductwork
Proceed with the ductwork installation.
Holding the filter in position requires the installation of a filter rack. The 
filter rack is usually located between the furnace casing and the return-
air plenum.
Impact of Filters on Air Flow
Resistance to Air Flow
All media filters, whether mechanical or electrostatic, add resistance to air flow.
Thickness Considerations
The thickness of the filter and the specifications for the furnace must match. Adding extra filters to the filter chamber to 
improve indoor air quality can seriously impede furnace operation.
Primary Purpose
The main purpose of the furnace inline filter is to protect the blower fan and heat exchanger from the dust, hair, and other 
particles the return duct pulls in.
Operational Issues
As a filter fills with particles, the air volume flowing through the filter decreases. Restrictions in air flow can cause problems in 
heating cycles, causing the furnace to switch off on the high limit control and seriously limit the furnace's ability to heat the 
house.

Types of Media Filters
Hammock Filters
Located on a frame or hammock that surrounds the fan in the forced-air furnace
If a forced-air furnace is intended to be used with a hammock filter, the filter holder will be factory installed
Slab Filters
Consist of layers of filter material, usually fibreglass, held in place by a cardboard frame
The fibres are treated with oil or a similar adhesive
Most slab filters are designed for one-time use and must be discarded when they are dirty
Pleated Filters
Represent the most popular type of filter choice available today
Come in a variety of sizes and thicknesses
Paper pleating increases the filter surface and improves performance
Hammock Filter
Description
Hammock filters are located on a frame or hammock that surrounds the fan in the forced-air furnace.
The filter material is typically disposable and requires periodic replacement.
Installation
If a forced-air furnace is intended to be used with a hammock filter, the filter holder will be factory installed.
The filter material is secured to the frame with screws or clips that can be loosened for replacement.
Maintenance
Regular inspection and replacement of the filter material is necessary.
One side of the media is usually coated with oil to enhance particle collection. This coated side should be opposite the blower.
Slab and Pleated Filters
Slab Filters
Consist of layers of filter material, usually fibreglass, held in place by a cardboard frame.
The fibres are treated with oil or a similar adhesive. Filters for residential use are usually about one inch thick.
Most slab filters are designed for one-time use and must be discarded when they are dirty.
Pleated Filters
Represent the most popular type of filter choice available today. They come in a variety of sizes and thicknesses.
Paper pleating increases the filter surface and improves performance.
A 5 inch depth pleated media filter can replace an electronic air filter and reside in the same cabinet, or a custom air filter rack can be installed to accommodate the size.
Filter Rack Installation
Locate the Installation Position
Identify the location of the racks. The side of the furnace cabinet will likely have embossed angles indicating the location.
Cut the Return Opening
Cut the return opening using the angles as guides.
Mount the Filter Rack
Mount the filter rack over the opening.
Complete Ductwork
Proceed with the ductwork installation.
Holding the filter in position requires the installation of a filter rack. The filter rack is usually located between the furnace casing and the return-air plenum.

CSA Unit 23 - Forced Air Add-On Devices Test
100 Multiple Choice Questions with Answer Key
Chapter 1: Air Filters and Cleaners
What is the minimum efficiency reporting value (MERV) rating system used for? A) Measuring airflow velocity B) Identifying filtering ability of furnace filters C) Calculating energy consumption D) Determining duct sizing
What MERV rating range is adequate for most homes? A) 1-4 B) 5-7 C) 8-11 D) 17-20
Which type of filter physically removes particles from the air stream? A) Electronic air cleaner B) Electrostatic precipitator C) Media filter D) UV air purifier
What does HEPA stand for? A) High-efficiency particulate air B) High-energy particle arrestor C) High-efficiency pressure accumulator D) High-energy pneumatic apparatus
What voltage range do electronic air cleaners typically operate at for the ionization section? A) 120V AC B) 240V AC C) 3000-3500V DC D) 7500-8500V DC
Which component of an electronic air cleaner captures larger particles before they enter the electrostatic field? A) Collector plates B) Pre-filter C) Ionizing wires D) Power pack
What is the typical temperature drop across a properly functioning cooling coil at 24C and 50% humidity? A) 5C (9F) B) 11C (20F) C) 15C (27F) D) 20C (36F)
How often should filters be inspected during heating season? A) Weekly B) Monthly C) Quarterly D) Annually
What happens when filters become more efficient (higher MERV ratings)? A) They create less resistance to airflow B) They create more resistance to airflow C) Airflow resistance remains constant D) They only work in summer
Which particles are most dangerous to human health? A) Visible particles B) Respirable particles that are exhaled C) Particles that enter and lodge in the lungs D) Large outdoor particles
What type of filter generates a static charge in response to air flow? A) Media filter B) Electrostatic air filter C) Electronic air cleaner D) HEPA filter
Where should hammock filters be positioned in relation to the blower? A) On the supply side B) On the return side C) Both sides equally D) It doesn't matter
What is the main purpose of the furnace inline filter? A) Improve indoor air quality B) Protect blower fan and heat exchanger C) Reduce energy consumption D) Control humidity levels
What can cause floodback in air conditioning systems? A) Too much airflow B) Dirty filters reducing airflow C) Low refrigerant levels D) High outdoor temperatures
Which side of a hammock filter media should be coated with oil? A) The side facing the blower B) The side opposite the blower C) Both sides equally D) Neither side
What is the correct procedure for cleaning disposable filters? A) Vacuum them monthly B) Wash with detergent C) Replace them, don't clean D) Use compressed air
How should electrostatic filters be cleaned when lightly soiled? A) Replace immediately B) Vacuum upstream side first, then downstream C) Wash with hot water only D) Use chemical solvents
What is the voltage range for the collector plates in an electronic air cleaner? A) 120V AC B) 240V AC C) 3000-3500V DC D) 7500-8500V DC
What should you do before cleaning electronic air cleaner cells? A) Increase the voltage B) Turn off power and discharge cells C) Remove only the pre-filter D) Check the humidity level
Which cleaning method is NOT recommended for EAC cells? A) Dishwasher without dry cycle B) Soaking in hot water with detergent C) Bathtub cleaning D) Car wash cleaning
Chapter 2: Humidifiers
What does relative humidity (RH%) measure? A) The total amount of water in the air B) The percentage of water vapor in air compared to saturation at the same temperature C) The temperature of water vapor D) The speed of air movement
What is the recommended relative humidity range for most building occupants? A) 10-20% B) 20-30% C) 30-50% D) 60-80%
At what outside temperature should maximum indoor RH be 40%? A) -7C B) -12C C) -18C D) -24C
What is the basic control for a humidifier? A) Thermostat B) Humidistat C) Pressure switch D) Flow meter
Which type of humidifier contains a 24V AC motor and foam-covered wheel? A) Spray humidifier B) Steam humidifier C) Drum humidifier D) Evaporator-pad humidifier
What connects the evaporator-pad humidifier between plenums? A) Water line only B) Electrical connection only C) Bypass duct D) Drain line only
Which humidifier type should NOT be used with hard water? A) Drum humidifiers B) Steam humidifiers C) Atomizing humidifiers D) Evaporator-pad humidifiers
How do self-contained steam humidifiers generate steam? A) Gas burner heating B) Hot water circulation C) Two electrodes causing water to boil D) Solar energy collection
Where should the humidistat be mounted to avoid incorrect readings? A) Near windows and doors B) In bathrooms and kitchens C) In return air duct or controlled area D) Outside the building
What happens if an atomizing humidifier operates when the furnace blower is not running? A) It works more efficiently B) It uses less water C) Water drops accumulate causing moisture problems D) Nothing, it operates normally
Why must the steam humidifier dispersion tube be mounted higher than the humidifier? A) Better steam distribution B) To allow condensate to drain back C) Easier maintenance access D) Building code requirement
What device can provide independent measure of relative humidity? A) Thermometer B) Barometer C) Sling psychrometer D) Voltmeter
What should be done with the bypass duct damper in summer? A) Leave it open B) Close it C) Adjust it to 50% open D) Remove it completely
If a humidistat is functioning but relative humidity doesn't match the setting, what might be the problem? A) Low water pressure B) Incorrect calibration C) Blocked drain D) Dirty filter media
What causes white dust throughout a home when using a humidifier? A) Dirty air filters B) Mineral deposits from hard water C) Excessive humidity D) Poor ventilation
How often should drum-type humidifier media be cleaned or replaced? A) Monthly during operation B) At the beginning of every season C) Only when it breaks D) Every two years
What is the recommended minimum mounting height for a humidifier above the furnace body? A) 1 inch (25 mm) B) 2 inches (51 mm) C) 3 inches (78 mm) D) 6 inches (152 mm)
Which electrical connection method should be avoided for humidifiers? A) Separate transformer B) Direct connection to thermostat circuit C) Independent circuit breaker D) Ground fault protection
What safety device ensures atomizing humidifiers only operate when the blower runs? A) Pressure switch B) Temperature sensor C) Sail switch D) Timer relay
What is the maximum recommended relative humidity at -18C outside temperature? A) 20% B) 25% C) 30% D) 35%
Chapter 3: Cooling Coils
Who typically performs the installation and major servicing of cooling coils? A) Gas technicians/fitters B) Refrigeration and air conditioning mechanics C) Plumbers D) Electricians
What is another name for the cooling coil due to its shape? A) U coil B) S coil C) A coil D) L coil
What is the normal air temperature drop across a cooling coil at typical conditions? A) 5C (9F) B) 8C (14F) C) 11C (20F) D) 15C (27F)
Where should temperature measurement holes be placed in plenums? A) One foot from the furnace B) Two feet from the furnace C) Three feet from the furnace D) Four feet from the furnace
How long should equipment operate before taking temperature measurements? A) 2 minutes B) 5 minutes C) 10 minutes D) 15 minutes
What indicates a refrigerant leak in the cooling coil system? A) Ice formation B) Spots of oil C) Excessive noise D) Low air temperature
What should be used to clear a clogged condensate drain? A) Chemical drain cleaner B) Hot water only C) Compressed air or nitrogen D) Wire brush
How do you calculate the temperature drop across a cooling coil? A) Add supply and return temperatures B) Subtract supply temperature from return temperature C) Multiply supply by return temperature D) Divide return by supply temperature
What problems occur during heating season if cooling coils are dirty? A) Lower stack temperature B) Increased temperature rise and stack temperature C) No effect on heating D) Improved heating efficiency
What tool should be used carefully when cleaning cooling coil fins? A) Pressure washer B) Steel brush C) Fin comb D) Sandpaper

Which filter type is most popular today? A) Hammock filters B) Slab filters C) Pleated filters D) Electronic filters
What is the primary disadvantage of HEPA filters for inline furnace use? A) Too expensive B) Too restrictive, could stall HVAC fan C) Not effective enough D) Require frequent replacement
How often should UV lamps typically be replaced? A) Every 3 months B) Every 6 months C) Every 9-12 months D) Every 2 years
What type of UV light is germicidal? A) UVA B) UVB C) UVC D) UVD
Which humidifier component controls water level automatically? A) Solenoid valve B) Float valve C) Pressure regulator D) Flow meter
What causes crackling sounds in an electronic air cleaner? A) Normal operation B) Dirty cells or arcing C) Low voltage D) High humidity
Where should electronic air cleaners be installed relative to humidifiers? A) Downstream from humidifier B) Upstream from humidifier C) Side by side D) In separate ducts
What is the recommended cleaning frequency for EAC cells? A) Every week B) Every 1-6 months C) Once per year D) Only when they break
Which method should NOT be used to connect water supply to a humidifier? A) Full-size tee fitting B) Approved valve C) Saddle valve D) Compression fitting
What is the main health concern with visible dust particles? A) They are the most dangerous B) They indicate presence of harmful invisible particles C) They cause immediate illness D) They damage HVAC equipment
How should ionizing wires be handled in electronic air cleaners? A) With bare
